job_title: Construction Project Manager in Boston, MA
pros: MEE is a great place to work with motivated individuals who are passionate about the work they are doing. Becoming part of MGB has allowed for growth in many areas of MEE. Location is great, super easy to get to. Plenty going on in the area for after work (parks, yoga, gyms, bars, restaurants, etc.) Great networking opportunities.
cons: MEE is a bit behind the times technically - they are not using the most updated technologies at times and there are a lot of people who have been around a long time who are a bit resistant to this change. Once this transition takes more hold I believe a lot will improve. Can be very political at times, but what hospital isn't? With such a small hospital, politics and rumors can spread like wildfire but that also means if you are a great team player and employee that information has just as much opportunity to spread.

pros: Great People to work with

pros: Name recognition may help find a job outside of this institution.
cons: The training environment and treatment of postdoctoral fellows in research leaves a lot to be desired.  Aside from mandatory seminars that fellows are required to present within the first two years of their appointment, there are no other training guidelines is place.  The seminars are not attended by the faculty, typically including the presenters mentor, and no feedback is given to usually very poor quality talks.  The chair and vice chair are mostly disengaged from the training program.  For the most part, mentors are not interested in promoting the careers of their fellows.  This is widely known within the institution because the postdocs have formed a group to attempt to better their situation, and many of these topics are discussed throughout the group.  Mass Eye and Ear has gone through extensive lengths to deny postdocs basic benefits that every other employee receives.  In fact, they do not consider postdocs employees.  They refuse to require mentors to pay their postdocs, while many other institutions specifically have minimum pay guidelines.  Additionally, there are restrictive computing guidelines that inhibit basic research in the name of protection of patient information, yet they recently lost employee personal information including SSN, bank account information, address.  This institution is designed to promote the top few on the backs of the everyone else.

review_title: How do we make money from hospital operations?
pros: The cafeteria serves excellent food at a 10% of discount to employees. Many of the nurses have been with them over 20 years. It provides relatively good care and some care that very few other places are equipped to provide.
cons: My boss considered eating lunch to be a luxury. She very much wanted everyone to work overtime even if someone understood their job and could do it efficiently. The better the quality of your work the more you were given to do. If hospital operations do not make money, then you are going to lose money because the cost of health insurance or another benefit will go up faster than your paycheck.

pros: The Doctors i work with are the BEST! The most renowned  and well  stablished yet down to earth professsionals.
cons: Too many "kids" working there. A very "back stabbing", "pulling the rug under your feet" kind of environment. Politics rule. ALWAYS UNDER staffed so we are expected to be shuffed between departments and overperform/work. Don't expect to get UNPAID lunch covereage/break neither! Rarelly happens, unless you fight for it. I am getting it now, after 3 years on the job.

review_title: If you have any ambition at all....stay away!
pros: Laid-back work environment. Had the opportunity to learn, but even this was limited. Low chance of being fired for any reason whatsoever.
cons: This was the sixth place I've worked during my professional career and MEEI is by far the most disorganized place I've ever worked at. Mediocre compensation and benefits. People can work 20 hours a week and get paid for fulltime work with no consequence/issues/anyone caring. If you're looking to spend 30 years of your career at one place and have no pressure, oversight or learning opportunities then this is the place for you! Basically, no one gives a flying fig.

review_title: Great place and people, but poor interdepartmental communication and management structure
pros: This hospital is able to recruit the best and brightest physicians and researchers, making it an inspiring place to work.
cons: Departments do not communicate, leading to a lot of wasted time, energy, and morale.  Was also pretty concerned about the training of middle/senior management.  It was pretty clear (from several examples during my time there) that promotions were generally a result of longevity and "playing politics" with the right people, rather than demonstrating excellence in leadership and/or managing a team.

review_title: management is biased and condescending ...save yourself
job_title: Medical Administrative Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: time off is the only good thing
cons: Employees have to find their own coverage for vacations and time off. No camaraderie between departments. The culture is terrible and every man for themselves. Management walks around giving orders and disappear when needed. It's like high school full of cliques. Discouraging to apply for other jobs because apparently you can be blocked to advance from within.

pros: People are very nice, it feels like a big family after a while. There have been a lot of changes in our software systems so I am always learning something new. The management in my dept is very supportive and easy to talk to. They always have time or make time to listen to questions or concerns.
cons: Overall too many managers and poor communication in some areas. No employee incentives. Very few opportunities to advance in each department.

pros: Exceptional staff and surgeons in OR. Referral patients practice makes clinical challenges a daily responsibility. Diverse Anesthesia Team with close knot relationships and friendly environment. Call is limited so not too many long nights. Harvard medical school academics, residents and wonderful teaching opportunities
cons: Limited clinical cases (ENT Ophtho). Can be very busy days with frequent add-ons that run rooms late. Hard to get promoted academically since MGH must sponsor your promotion and they have little interest in seeing MEEI staff promoted- expensive to park.

review_title: A Small Specialty Hospital with Huge Outpatient Clinics
pros: The benefits are reasonable, the cafeteria was good. Vacation and sick time are separate. Close to the Red Line, 1/2 a mile from North Station.
cons: Although there are leadership meetings once a month, your boss is the conduit between you and the rest of the hospital. High silos create many barriers between departments. People think this is a Partners instituion and it is no.t

review_title: Working there as an RN for six years, zero advancement, crap pay
pros: nice employees, close knit departments, caring to new nurses
cons: The money is horrible, administration is top heavy, very political advancement only, HR has no grip on middle management (probably because they are all buddies), cheap cheap cheap company both for patients and new employees. NEEDS A UNION. Building huge per diem pools instead of creating benefited jobs,75% department turnover-what does that tell you?

pros:
Decent benefits
Collegial coworkers
Appealing research
MEEI is a decent place to work.  It is not as hectic as Mass. General, but there are still deadlines.
cons:
Flat Organizational hierarchy; not a lot of room for upward advancement unless you are a physician.  
MEEI pretends to be an academic organization; It is not.  It's a hospital, ie a business.  When decisions are made, it's the bottom line (money) that matters.

pros: Exciting atmosphere to assist in the medical profession even if just in an Orderly role.  Gain a great appreciation for the medical field and the tremendous work that the nurses do.  I worked part time while in college and would be a great fit for a young person that is possibly interested in pursuing a career as a nurse or similar.
cons: Have to deal with blood, bodily fluids etc, but that's the reality...

job_title: Medical Administrative Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: The physicians are awesome to work with and the staff members are really helpful. Team work is very important to make sure patients received the highest quality of care.
cons: The low pay and poor management make the work atmosphere draining.  As an employee, the management makes you feel small and insignificant.
